DOC.HEAD: Terrorism Reward Increased to $2 Million
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government Monday quadrupled _ to $2 million _ the maximum reward it can offer to anyone who provides information that helps thwart an act of terrorism. The money can be paid to ``any person who furnishes information that leads to the prevention, frustration or favorable resolution of a terrorist act against U.S. persons or property,'' the State Department said in a brief announcement. The increase was made possible by a provision in an anti-drug bill passed by Congress and signed into law by President Bush last week. Rewards had been limited to $500,000. ``We believe this increase will strengthen U.S. efforts to prevent terrorist attacks and will help bring terrorists to justice,'' the statement said. Anyone with information about planned terrorist acts should call the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate if they are overseas, or contact the FBI if they are in the United States, it said. The announcement came three days after the department issued an unusual public terrorism alert, warning of the possibility of an attack on U.S. targets in Western Europe or west Africa. Concern for such an attack was based on recent reports of movement of terrorists from the Middle East and the discovery of weapons shipments destined for pro-Iranian groups in Spain and Africa. It also reflected concern that terrorists might seek to use violence to observe the anniversaries of the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 or other attacks that have taken place during the holiday season.
